title: Mordor After the Fall… is Still Just Mordor I Guess
description: Mordor, eh?  Cool.  So what do you guys do for fun around here? -Me, just before finding out and logging off I don’t know what I expected. It is, however, classic Wilhelm Arcturus behavior to set a goal, strive to meet it, and then, upon arrival, to end up being disappointed with the result and […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: Mordor, eh? Cool. So what do you guys do for fun around here? -Me, just before finding out and logging off I don’t know what I expected. It is, however, classic Wilhelm Arcturus behavior to…
text: Mordor, eh?  Cool.  So what do you guys do for fun around here? -Me, just before finding out and logging off I don’t know what I expected. There it is… Mordor It is, however, classic Wilhelm Arcturus behavior to set a goal, strive to meet it, and then, upon arrival, to end up being disappointed with the result and walk away.  There was getting to maximum mining skills in EVE Online, after which I barely ever mined again, or doing the daily gem hunt in Need for Speed World until I got the final achievement at 180 days only to stop playing, or even doing the Nat Pagle dailies in Pandaria to get that water strider mount, only to be pretty much done with the expansion after that, it is the sort of thing I seem to do.  I set a goal rather than charting a journey, and when the goal is met I find my self burnt out on the whole thing. But I am getting ahead of myself here.  Let’s go back to where I left off, which was in a nice little glen in Ithilien and an invite to go and visit cheery and recently liberated Mordor. Going to the right place and time I got on the horse and rode back into Mordor, the destination I had sought over these past four months, having traveled back and forth across Middle-earth many times to get there. At the gates I met Prince Imrahil who had a quest for me that sent me into Mordor.  Great!  I wanted to go there anyway.  So I mount off and headed on down the road… and, it was pretty neat looking.  I liked it. Headed into Mordor Cool ruins, lots of nice fire effects, an overall orange glow.  Good stuff. I got to the first camp of the host of the west or whatever they are calling themselves now and picked up a couple of quests, but ended up being directed to King Eomer of Rohan… though why the hell he was standing around in the ruins of Mordor handing out quests was left unexplained… it seems like he might have more important tasks to see to… who was there waiting for me. Eomer has to do time as a quest giver He was there to tell me about Allegiances, a whole new concept there in Mordor, helpfully directing me to the menu location where I could find them. The menu location, as explained by the king of Rohan Going there meant making me choose an allegiance.  In the Lucky Charms selection available, I had frivolous hobbits, grumpy dwarves, check-out elves, and doughty men of Gondor.  I chose the latter, it seeming to be the least worst option. The men of Gondor await Choosing that, I had to turn around and ride back up the road I had just ridden down to speak once again to Prince Imrahil, traffic cop of the black gate. Back out the way I came Along the way I adjusted a new bit of UI that was somehow related to allegiances. A pocket watch or something I had to fiddle with that because thing because, while you can scale up bits of the UI, it doesn’t scale in any intelligent way, so this ended up merged with the enlarged mini-map. Along the way back I also checked my in-game email, which included an invite from Aragorn to his wedding… though not even a +1 for the effort.  I figured I might skip that.  Weddings can be so dull. When I got to Prince I, he told me that everybody was going back to Minas Tirith, but not for the wedding… not yet… but for another event. Cue “bring me everyone!” meme We had to go see Aragorn accept the crown and be officially installed as King of Gondor. The house of Telcontar is here We watched that, cheered when the quest demanded it, chatted a bit, then went and saw the king on his throne. They must have an industrial floor buffer to get that shine! Then it was back to Mordor, back to the first camp. There I looked at the quests available and there was the usual array of collect bits and pieces and scraps of paper, find some lost item, and kill some people. Kill some people?  Kill who?  Who is left to kill at this point? It appears that most of the residents of Mordor didn’t know what to do after the fall of the dark tower, so just got up the next morning and went back to work tending their infernal machines and checking people’s papers, and generally doing all the things that gave the place the reputation it had. So I went out to give it a try.  I mean, what else is a mysterious, heavily armed drifter with a history of violence going to do?  But my heart wasn’t really in it. Sure, there were a few people out there who just wanted to surrender and get on with life. I feel you man And there were some prisoners who had been made trustees and put to work hanging about, looking for somebody to set them free. Wait, how did you end up here? But mostly it was killing a bunch of mobs for updates.  With that the edge had kind of gone off that particular routine.  Up until this point, despite my history of violence, I had been slaying mobs that stood between me and my goal.  There was at least some purpose in that, some progress to be made, and some aspect of the story to be served by killing another orc for another deed update in another region of Middle-earth. Now, however, the story was done.  Or, at least the story I cared about, the meta story that started back in Bree and The Shire and Ered Luin and that I chased across the Barrow Downs, over the Lone Lands, around Angmar, through Dunland, into Rohan then Gondor, and finally to the Black Gate itself… that story ended with the destruction of the one ring and the return of the king. It might not even be the fact that I achieved my goal or reaching Mordor.  It might be more that the story beyond this point, the people and places I have yet to see, do not have any real hold on me.  Past this point we’re really digging into the appendix at the end of the third book, mining it for side tales and obscure places. As the hobbits discuss in the books, no story ever ends.  Each just leads on to the next situation and then the next.  But at some point your part in the story ends.  If we were off to see the end of Saurman or the scourging of The Shire or even see the departure at the Grey Havens… and SSG is working hard to put off the date of that particular scene I am sure… I might be invested. Or maybe I just made it to my goal and am feeling done.  We’ll see.  But for now I think I have hit the end of the trail.  The Mordor Project has been successfully completed.  I will likely have a couple of follow on posts about some aspects of the game, like the updated legendary item system. And the nice thing about having a lifetime subscription is that I can come and go as I please. Besides which, it is almost time for Mists of Pandaria, isn’t it?  I need to go get that water strider mount from Nat Pagle.
html:
Mordor, eh?  Cool.  So what do you guys do for fun around here?

-Me, just before finding out and logging off

I don’t know what I expected.

There it is… Mordor

It is, however, classic Wilhelm Arcturus behavior to set a goal, strive to meet it, and then, upon arrival, to end up being disappointed with the result and walk away.  There was getting to maximum mining skills in EVE Online, after which I barely ever mined again, or doing the daily gem hunt in Need for Speed World until I got the final achievement at 180 days only to stop playing, or even doing the Nat Pagle dailies in Pandaria to get that water strider mount, only to be pretty much done with the expansion after that, it is the sort of thing I seem to do.  I set a goal rather than charting a journey, and when the goal is met I find my self burnt out on the whole thing.

But I am getting ahead of myself here.  Let’s go back to where I left off, which was in a nice little glen in Ithilien and an invite to go and visit cheery and recently liberated Mordor.

Going to the right place and time

I got on the horse and rode back into Mordor, the destination I had sought over these past four months, having traveled back and forth across Middle-earth many times to get there.

At the gates I met Prince Imrahil who had a quest for me that sent me into Mordor.  Great!  I wanted to go there anyway.  So I mount off and headed on down the road… and, it was pretty neat looking.  I liked it.

Headed into Mordor

Cool ruins, lots of nice fire effects, an overall orange glow.  Good stuff.

I got to the first camp of the host of the west or whatever they are calling themselves now and picked up a couple of quests, but ended up being directed to King Eomer of Rohan… though why the hell he was standing around in the ruins of Mordor handing out quests was left unexplained… it seems like he might have more important tasks to see to… who was there waiting for me.

Eomer has to do time as a quest giver

He was there to tell me about Allegiances, a whole new concept there in Mordor, helpfully directing me to the menu location where I could find them.

The menu location, as explained by the king of Rohan

Going there meant making me choose an allegiance.  In the Lucky Charms selection available, I had frivolous hobbits, grumpy dwarves, check-out elves, and doughty men of Gondor.  I chose the latter, it seeming to be the least worst option.

The men of Gondor await

Choosing that, I had to turn around and ride back up the road I had just ridden down to speak once again to Prince Imrahil, traffic cop of the black gate.

Back out the way I came

Along the way I adjusted a new bit of UI that was somehow related to allegiances.

A pocket watch or something

I had to fiddle with that because thing because, while you can scale up bits of the UI, it doesn’t scale in any intelligent way, so this ended up merged with the enlarged mini-map.

Along the way back I also checked my in-game email, which included an invite from Aragorn to his wedding… though not even a +1 for the effort.  I figured I might skip that.  Weddings can be so dull.

When I got to Prince I, he told me that everybody was going back to Minas Tirith, but not for the wedding… not yet… but for another event.

Cue “bring me everyone!” meme

We had to go see Aragorn accept the crown and be officially installed as King of Gondor.

The house of Telcontar is here

We watched that, cheered when the quest demanded it, chatted a bit, then went and saw the king on his throne.

They must have an industrial floor buffer to get that shine!

Then it was back to Mordor, back to the first camp.

There I looked at the quests available and there was the usual array of collect bits and pieces and scraps of paper, find some lost item, and kill some people.

Kill some people?  Kill who?  Who is left to kill at this point?

It appears that most of the residents of Mordor didn’t know what to do after the fall of the dark tower, so just got up the next morning and went back to work tending their infernal machines and checking people’s papers, and generally doing all the things that gave the place the reputation it had.

So I went out to give it a try.  I mean, what else is a mysterious, heavily armed drifter with a history of violence going to do?  But my heart wasn’t really in it.

Sure, there were a few people out there who just wanted to surrender and get on with life.

I feel you man

And there were some prisoners who had been made trustees and put to work hanging about, looking for somebody to set them free.

Wait, how did you end up here?

But mostly it was killing a bunch of mobs for updates.  With that the edge had kind of gone off that particular routine.  Up until this point, despite my history of violence, I had been slaying mobs that stood between me and my goal.  There was at least some purpose in that, some progress to be made, and some aspect of the story to be served by killing another orc for another deed update in another region of Middle-earth.

Now, however, the story was done.  Or, at least the story I cared about, the meta story that started back in Bree and The Shire and Ered Luin and that I chased across the Barrow Downs, over the Lone Lands, around Angmar, through Dunland, into Rohan then Gondor, and finally to the Black Gate itself… that story ended with the destruction of the one ring and the return of the king.

It might not even be the fact that I achieved my goal or reaching Mordor.  It might be more that the story beyond this point, the people and places I have yet to see, do not have any real hold on me.  Past this point we’re really digging into the appendix at the end of the third book, mining it for side tales and obscure places.

As the hobbits discuss in the books, no story ever ends.  Each just leads on to the next situation and then the next.  But at some point your part in the story ends.  If we were off to see the end of Saurman or the scourging of The Shire or even see the departure at the Grey Havens… and SSG is working hard to put off the date of that particular scene I am sure… I might be invested.

Or maybe I just made it to my goal and am feeling done.  We’ll see.  But for now I think I have hit the end of the trail.  The Mordor Project has been successfully completed.  I will likely have a couple of follow on posts about some aspects of the game, like the updated legendary item system.

And the nice thing about having a lifetime subscription is that I can come and go as I please.

Besides which, it is almost time for Mists of Pandaria, isn’t it?  I need to go get that water strider mount from Nat Pagle.
